awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Development of Modern Commercialism
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation project investigates the ways in which expanding markets and the commodification of labor and resources transform local, self-sufficient economies and societies. Commodification is at the core of the modern global economy and was a key development in the formation of market economies in the past.  It has long been recognized that European colonialism unleashed commodification worldwide accompanied by new productive agendas, market-based consumer patterns, and even ecological rearrangements via species introductions, depletions, and extinctions. Colonial conquest brought commodification and mercantilism to many parts of the world as part of spreading the first global economy, but did this process build on prior forms of commodification and specialization?   How did local populations for example engage with the overarching Spanish market order, and conversely, how were market mentalities and practices shaped by native economic arrangements? How were new hybrid productive structures and practices born in colonial settings as market logics met native patterns?  These questions remain important subjects of investigation to better understand globalization dynamics, past and the present.  

Using an archaeological perspective this research examines how indigenous economic practices, largely based on self-sufficiency, reciprocity and redistribution, confronted a mercantile praxis based on the commodification of labor and natural resources. The doctoral student examines an indigenous maritime hunter-gatherer community as this place was transformed into an important early colonial port. Diverse archeological and archival lines of evidence on community composition, occupation specialization, production and consumption (from diet and personal possessions to fishing gear and impact on fishing stocks) are integrated to track changes in socioeconomic life and habitat of residents (both indigenous and colonial) from the prehispanic through early colonial periods.  A well preserved archaeological setting provides an unparalleled opportunity to radiocarbon date at the fine scale important changes in these lines of evidence, generating critical information on the timing and sequences of change relating to commodification and market practices. Such a study provides a vivid picture of an understudied settlement type - - the early colonial port - - as a revealing, diverse workforce community, and provides an archaeological case study at the dawn of commodification processes.  This knowledge furthers comparative understanding of the dynamics of initial commercial nodes and the hybrid nature of the early colonial markets generally.   In addition, the close study of habitat change (marine and terrestrial) by the research team advances environmental archaeology on the topics of Anthropocene habitat change and overfishing.  Collaboration with local institutions offer students research materials and training opportunities in archaeology and biochemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Archaeological remains of everyday production and consumption can provide a critical window onto natives’ market participation and commodification processes in the Americas following the arrival of Europeans.  This project, one of the first to investigate archaeologically an early Colonial port in South America, provides such information for native and European populations for Puerto Loa (Atacama Desert, northern Chile).  Within the anthropological debate about market universality, the societies of the pre-Columbian Andes have long been held up as the leading examples of complex, non-market societies, in which market behaviors were absent or only marginal. Commodification of Andean resources would be, therefore, represent a European early modern imposition and adaptation. This project explored the supposed Andean dis-embeddedness of social complexity and markets at the genesis of a unique colonial Andean market in the Andes.  This project thus informed on how native patterns were incorporated into a new, overarching market economy setting as well as how European market institutions altered in negotiation with native economic logic and praxis.

Excavations at Puerto Loa revealed a deep sequence of shifting episodes, intensive fishing events, technological transformations, salting and processing areas, and regional and overseas commodity arrivals. We uncovered how native populations engaged with the overarching expanding market order and how the market adjusted to native structures and economic praxis.

The project examined: (1) how native seafood production shifted and commodified under the Spanish, as compared to late pre-Columbian times; (2) concomitant socioeconomic and consumption changes, including market access among native households; and (3) the effects of port development and changing production practices on local resources.

The NSF grant covered the radiocarbon dating component of the research, specifically the processing of15 carefully selected AMS radiocarbon samples, all critical to track the changes triggered by native’s participation in the expanding colonial Andean market. To directly address the research objectives concerning the trans-Conquest economic shifts, eight samples from a carefully excavated unit at the core of the native village and seven from the core of the early colonial Spanish houses and fishery were radiocarbon dated.

The resulting calibrated dates evidenced the long-term human settlement of Loa with four main episodes: an earlier late Formative settlement during the last five centuries cal BC; an enduring occupation during the middle centuries of the first millennium AD and late pre-Columbian deposits at both sectors; plus, the early colonial occupation of the native village and Iberian fishery during the early 17th century.

The high precision radiocarbon AMS dates from Loa document the long-term occupation of this part of ancient Peru but also meaningful changes in fish commodification. Fish salting was the main innovation discovered at the site. The AMS available results demonstrated that the associated salt beds and the excavated salting patios at Loa, from where thousands of fish bones, scales and even salted-fish meat were recovered, represent a colonial response to market demands by highland mining cities like Potosi. Iberian colonists ran the fishery with the help of regional ethnic leaders and traditional native communal fishing labor.

Seafood commodification was an Iberian innovation among Andean fishermen in the southern Viceroyalty. Ichthyology (fish bones) analyzes showed that colonial productive changes didn’t entail the reduction of fish size due to overfishing: colonial fishing at the site intensified in terms of the range of species and habitat exploited by the Spaniards and their native workforce.

The consumption patterns of the local native community evidenced little changes through time as their communal production reoriented to solve the demands of the new colonial cities. Like their pre-Columbian predecessors, following Spanish Conquest the native population continued to consume their favorite fish species, Andean regional cultigens (i.e., corn and others), camelids, chicha (beer made with maize and other local plants) and foraged plants as seen through macro and micro remains (phytoliths). Layers radiocarbon dated as late as cal AD 1623-1670 show a picture of communal self-sufficiency and Andean traditional economic relations.

In sum, our AMS results documented a long-term occupation of the settlement by specialized Andean fishers, their fishing toolkits and gear and a strong degree of continuity in economic praxis even relatively late into colonial times. The most evident changes in production, distribution, and consumption for Loa’s inhabitants occurred in early colonial times when a new elite constituted by a mixture of powerful Iberians and regional caciques benefited from the political implantation of a new kind of economic organization in the Andes: the early modern market. Even if local natives provided the necessary labor for commodification, the new local elite enjoyed the monetary retribution of the enterprise.
